JECHEM 241 S2095-4956(16)30378-3 10.1016/j.jechem.2016.11.017 Science Press Fig. 1 (a) XRD patterns of (1) Co3O4/Ni and (2) Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites. (b) EDS spectrums of Co3O4/Co3V2O8 samples scratched from the Ni foam. Fig 1 Fig. 2 SEM images of (a) Co3O4/Ni and (b, c) Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites. TEM images of (d) Co3O4/Ni and (e) Co3O4/Co3V2O8 samples scratched from the Ni foam. (f) HRTEM images and the selected area electron diffraction pattern of Co3O4/Co3V2O8 samples. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Illustration of formation processes of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) The CV curves of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites for the first three cycles. (b) The ex-situ XRD patterns of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites under different discharge and charge states. Fig 4 Fig. 5 The charge-discharge curves of (a) Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni and (b) Co3O4/Ni nanocomposites for the different cycles at 100mA/g. (c) The cycling performances of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni and Co3O4/Ni nanocomposites at 100mA/g. (d) The rate capabilities of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni and Co3O4/Ni nanocomposites at various current densities. (e) Long cycling performance of the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites at current density of 1 A/g. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a, b) The SEM and (c, d) TEM images of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites after 100 cycles at 100mA/g with different magnifications. (e–h) The selected TEM area and the corresponding EDS elemental mapping images of Co, V, and O, respectively. Fig 6 Fig. 7 EIS spectra of (a) the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites after different cycles and (b) fresh Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni and Co3O4/Ni nanocomposites. Fig 7 The design and fabrication of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites as high-performance anodes for Li-ion batteries Li Yang a Kong Lingbin a b * Liu Maocheng a b Zhang Weibin a Kang Long a b a State Key Laboratory of Advanced Processing and Recycling of Non-ferrous Metals, Lanzhou University of Technology, Lanzhou 730050, Gansu, China State Key Laboratory of Advanced Processing and Recycling of Non-ferrous Metals Lanzhou University of Technology Lanzhou Gansu 730050 China b School of Materials Science and Engineering, Lanzhou University of Technology, Lanzhou 730050, Gansu, China School of Materials Science and Engineering Lanzhou University of Technology Lanzhou Gansu 730050 China * Corresponding author at: State Key Laboratory of Advanced Processing and Recycling of Non-ferrous Metals, Lanzhou University of Technology, Lanzhou 730050, Gansu, China. Fax: +86 931 2976578. State Key Laboratory of Advanced Processing and Recycling of Non-ferrous Metals, Lanzhou University of Technology, Lanzhou 730050, Gansu, China. The Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites were rationally designed and prepared by a two-step hydrothermal synthesis and subsequent annealing treatment. The one-dimensional (1D) Co3O4 nanowire arrays directly grew on Ni foam, whereas the 1D Co3V2O8 nanowires adhered to parts of Co3O4 nanowires. Most of the hybrid nanowires were inlayed with each other, forming a 3D hybrid nanowires network. As a result, the discharge capacity of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites could reach 1201.8mAh/g after 100 cycles at 100mA/g. After 600 cycles at 1A/g, the discharge capacity was maintained at 828.1mAh/g. Moreover, even though the charge/discharge rates were increased to 10A/g, it rendered reversible capacity of 491.2mAh/g. The superior electrochemical properties of nanocomposites were probably ascribed to their unique 3D architecture and the synergistic effects of two active materials. Therefore, such Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites could potentially be used as anode materials for high-performance Li-ion batteries. Graphical abstract The three-dimensional Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites were rationally designed and fabricated through a stepwise hydrothermal method with subsequent thermal treatment, which exhibited outstanding Li-storage properties, ranking the nanocomposites as promising anode materials for high-performance Li-ion batteries. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Co3O4 Co3V2O8 Ni foam Nanocomposites Li-ion batteries 1 Introduction As one of the most important electrochemical storage devices, Li-ion batteries (LIBs) have been rapidly evolving in different applications, ranging from new generation of portable electronic devices to electric vehicles [1]. However, current commercialized graphite anode has the low theoretical capacity that hinders their further applications in LIBs [2,3]. This promotes intensive researches for alternative anode materials with high capacity and long cycling lifetime. Due to the much higher theoretical capacities over the commercially used graphite, transition metal oxides (TMOs) have been regarded as promising candidates as alternative anode materials for LIBs [4,5]. In particular, cobalt oxide (Co3O4) has been well regarded as distinguished anode due to their high capacity, good chemical/thermal stability, and low cost for synthesis [6–8]. However, their practical application is largely restrained by the low electrical conductivity, poor cycle stability and large volume expansion during the charge/discharge process. To address this problem, the first approach is to grow the active materials directly on conductive collectors, which can enhance their electronic conductivity and structure stability, leading to improved electrochemical performance [9,10]. Especially, the Ni foam has porous architecture with large surface area, good electronic conductivity and structure stability, which can be an ideal deposition substrate [11,12]. The second approach is to design binary metal oxides to improve electrochemical performances in view of their improved redox activity and electrical conductivity than that of single metal oxides [13–16]. Among them, binary metal Co3V2O8 based materials have been intensively studied as electrode materials for supercapacitors [17] and catalysis [18]. As a novel anode for LIBs, Co3V2O8 shows superior electrochemical activities, which may have potential application in LIBs [19]. Recently, much attention has been paid to a judicious design of nanostructured electrode materials and smart hybridization of two materials in synergy [20–26]. Such an electrode system has demonstrated enhanced electrochemical performances using rational design of nanocomposites in structure and component [27,28]. In particular, three-dimensional (3D) nanostructured electrodes are more attractive because they can take full advantages of different nanostructures and components, while offering good physical isolate with less aggregation during battery cycling to achieve superior electrochemical performances [29–31]. For instance, Kong et al. fabricated 3D Co3O4@MnO2 hierarchical nanoneedle arrays by a facile two-step hydrothermal, which presented improved electrochemical properties for LIBs compared to the single Co3O4 nanowires arrays [32]. Zheng synthesized Co3O4/Fe2O3 branched nanowire heterostructure via a two-step hydrothermal reaction to enhance the electrochemical performances [33]. Wu fabricated Co3O4/NiO/C nanowire arrays, which showed a high capacity (1053mAh/g) and good rate capability [34]. To date, different nanostructured single Co3O4 and Co3V2O8 have been synthesized and applied for LIBs [35–39]. Nevertheless, few studies have been performed concerning electrochemical performances of their 3D integrated electrodes on porous substrates by rationally combining merits of Co3O4 and Co3V2O8. In this study, we designed and fabricated Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites by a two-step hydrothermal synthesis and subsequent annealing treatment. The electrodes showed unique 3D architectures consisted of a large number of interlaced hybrid nanowires, in which the 1D Co3O4 nanowire arrays directly grew on Ni foam, and 1D Co3V2O8 nanowires inlayed and adhered to parts of Co3O4 nanowires. They exhibited outstanding electrochemical performances in terms of the high reversible capacity, outstanding long-life cycling stabilities and impressive high-rate capability. The improved lithium storage performances could be attributed to the 3D hybrid nanowires architecture and synergetic effects between Co3O4 and Co3V2O8 component. The proposed nanocomposites could be potentially used as anode materials for LIBs. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites Synthesis of Co3O4/Ni nanocomposites. The Co3O4/Ni nanocomposites were prepared by a routine hydrothermal synthesis method. In a typical synthesis, 0.93g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 160mL deionized water, followed by addition of 0.96g of CO(NH2)2 and 0.24g NH4F with continuous stirring. The mixture was transferred into a 200mL Teflon-lined autoclave, with insertion a piece of clean Ni foam, and hydrothermally treated in an oven at 100°C for 5h. The obtained Ni substrate with pink precipitates was washed with deionized water, and further heated in air at 350°C for 2h for subsequent processing. Synthesis of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites. The Ni foam substrate covered by Co3O4 nanowires was then used as the “substrate” to guide the growth of Co3V2O8 nanowires in the hydrothermal reaction. Next step was to dissolve 1.6g Na3VO4·12H2O and 1.55g CoCl2·6H2O in 160mL deionized water, then took the homogeneous solution into a 200mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave with insertion of the obtained Co3O4/Ni samples at 150°C for 6h growth. The formation mechanism of Co3V2O8 was: 2Na3VO4 +3CoCl2 →Co3V2O8 +6NaCl. After that, the samples were dried at 200°C for 12h under vacuum to obtain the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites. 2.2 Characterization of electrode materials The structure of the obtained products was examined with X-ray diffraction (XRD; Rigaku Co., D/MAX 2400 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation, λ=0.15418nm). The morphology and structure were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM; JEOL, JSM-6701F) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM; JEOL, JEM-2010) with energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS). Inductively coupled plasma (ICP-AES, IRIS Intrepid II XSP) was carried out to measure the element component of samples. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements The electrochemical performances were tested using CR-2032 coin-type cells. The Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites were directly used as the working electrodes. The mass loading of the active materials was around 1–1.5mg/cm2. All cells were assembly in an argon-filled glove box with a Li foil as the counter electrode, a Celgard 2300 membrane as the separator and a mixture of 1M LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate and dimethyl carbonate (1:1, by volume) as the electrolyte, and the amount of electrolyte was about 70–80µL. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were measured by the electrochemical workstation (CHI660C, Shanghai China). The charge−discharge cycling was performed by the lithium-ion battery cycler (LAND CT2001A, Wuhan China) at different current rates. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and structure characterization The XRD patterns in Fig. 1 (a) show the overall crystal structure and phase purity of the two as-obtained products: pristine Co3O4/Ni and Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites. All the diffraction peaks for the two samples fitted well with standard XRD patterns of Co3O4 (JCPDF: 65-3103) and Co3V2O8 (JCPDF: 16-0675) phases. The diffraction peaks at 31.4°, 36.9°, 59.6°, and 65.5° were correlated to the 220, 311, 511, and 440 reflections of Co3O4, respectively; whereas the diffraction peaks at 15.1°, 35.7°, 57.6° and 63.2° were associated with the 110, 311, 511and 440 reflections of Co3V2O8, respectively. No additional peaks from possible impurities were observed, indicating that the composites were made of Co3O4 and Co3V2O8 with high purity. In addition, EDS microanalysis of Co3O4/Co3V2O8 samples scratched from the Ni foam showed that products consisted of Co, V and O elements (Fig. 1(b)), which further confirmed that the nanocomposites were mainly made of Co3O4 and Co3V2O8. The presence of Cu peaks at the EDS spectrum was ascribed to the Cu wafer used as a support of the samples for TEM observation. The elemental compositions of the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites were further determined using ICP technique, Table S1 showed that Co/V atomic ratios were about 6.81:1, corresponding to around 32.3% (mass percentage) of Co3V2O8 in nanocomposites. The morphology and structure of the as-fabricated Co3O4/ Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites were characterized with SEM and TEM. As shown in Fig. 2 (a), the Co3O4 nanowires homogeneously grew on the surface of Ni foam with an average diameter of 50–100nm and lengths of around several microns. After two components integrated, Co3V2O8 nanowires inlayed and adhered to Co3O4 nanowires while inheriting the porous structure of the Ni foam (Figs. 2(b), 2(c), and S1). Most of the Co3O4 and Co3V2O8 nanowires were inlayed with each other, and some were aggregated to format bundles, forming a 3D hybrid nanowires network. Fig. 2(d) displayed the TEM image of a single Co3O4 nanowire, which composed of nanocrystallites of 10–20nm, whereas Fig. 2(e) was a typical TEM image of the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites, showing an interlaced hybrid nanowires network. This was consistent with the observation of the SEM images shown in Fig. 2(b) and (c). The HRTEM image showed a distinct set of visible lattice spacing of 0.468nm, which corresponded to the (111) plane of Co3O4. Furthermore, the SAED pattern of composites samples demonstrated their polycrystalline nature (The inset of Fig. 2(f)). The successful synthesis of 3D Co3V2O8/Co3O4/Ni nanocomposites offered an excellent anode candidate for LIBs. The primary Co3O4 nanowires and the secondary Co3V2O8 nanowires can synergistically serve as conduction channels for fast Li+ transport. In addition, this unique structure would provide good physical isolation between neighboring nanowires within a small footprint area, and take full advantages of bi-component active Co3O4 and Co3V2O8 nanowires, allowing for less agglomeration and permitting good electrolyte penetration during the cycling process to achieve outstanding electrochemical performances [5,29–33]. In order to explore the distribution of Co3V2O8 in the 3D hybrid structure and the formation processes of the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites, a series of time-dependent experiments were conducted and the samples obtained from various hydrothermal times were characterized by SEM, as shown in Fig. S2. With a short reaction time (2h), only small sized Co3V2O8 nanocrystals nucleated on the surface of parts of Co3O4 nanowires (Fig. S2(a)) and aggregated to form bundles. Interestingly, these Co3V2O8 bundles started to self-assemble by an oriented attachment, and aggregated into nanowires with further increasing the reaction time to 4h (Fig. S2(b)). When the reaction time increased to 6h, much larger-sized Co3V2O8 nanowires were formed (Fig. 2(b) and (c)). After 8h of reaction (Fig. S2(c)), the overall morphology of samples appeared no further obvious changes but became denser. On the basis of the above observation, we proposed a simple two-step growth process as illustrated in Fig. 3 . Firstly, the uniform Co3O4 nanowire arrays were grown on Ni foam through a facile hydrothermal synthesis method with subsequent heat-treatment. Secondly, the Co3O4 nanowires were then subjected to impregnate with Co2+ and VO4− aqueous solution, and the parts of Co3O4 nanowires were used as the “substrate” to guide the growth of Co3V2O8 nanowires in the hydrothermal reaction. Finally, these Co3V2O8 nanowires gradually grew and inlayed with Co3O4 nanowires, forming an intricate 3D hybrid nanowires network. 3.2 Electrochemical evaluation of the electrodes The electrochemical reaction of the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites was examined by the CV measurement as LIBs anodes for the first three cycles at a scan rate of 0.1mV/s in the range of 0.01–3.0V (versus Li/Li+) at room temperature as shown in Fig. 4 (a). In the first discharge curve, a reduction peak at around 1.14V could be assigned to the transformation of Co3V2O8 into CoO accompanied by the formation of Li x V2O5 [19,40]. A strong irreversible cathodic peak was observed at 0.68V, which was attributed to the reductions of Co3O4 to CoO and the formation of Li2O [41,42]. Another strong peak at 0.36V was detected corresponding to the further insertion of Li+ into the Li x V2O5 to form Li x+y V2O5 and reduction reactions of CoO to Co, companied with the irreversible formation of SEI film. During the subsequent cathodic scans, two reduction peaks at 0.86V and 1.51V were ascribed to insertion of Li+ into the Li x V2O5 and the reduction process from CoO to Co. The cyclic voltammogram for the first cycle was substantially different from those of the subsequent ones. This result demonstrated that drastic lithium driven, structure/textural rearrangement and modifications occurred. Two broader anodic peaks of the first cycle located at about 1.44V and 2.2V can be described as the oxidation of Co to CoO and the extraction of Li+ from the Li x V2O5. It was interesting that the area integrated within the current potential curves increased gradually along with scan number, leading to a much larger capacity. In order to further study the lithium storage mechanism of composites, a series of partially lithiated cells were selected in different states. The corresponding ex situ X-ray patterns were shown in Fig. 4(b). When the first discharging from the open circuit voltage to 1.14V, the Co3V2O8 phase gradually turned to the CoO phase (JCPDF card no. 70-2856) and amorphous Li x V2O5. When discharging to 0.68V, the Co3V2O8 phases disappeared, suggesting the reduction of all the Co3V2O8 into new phases. Meanwhile, the diffraction peaks of Co3O4 became weak and the diffraction peaks of CoO became strong, suggesting that the Co3O4 phase gradually turned to the CoO phase. In the subsequent discharging process, the CoO phase gradually disappeared, which can be attributed to a conversion reaction of CoO to Co companied with further insertion of Li+ into the Li x V2O5 to form Li x+y V2O5. In the subsequent charging process, the CoO phase reappeared with the increasing of charging degree, which could contribute to the oxidation of Co into CoO and the extraction of Li+ from Li x+y V2O5. In summary, the electrochemical reaction mechanism of the composite can be described by following equations: (1) Co3O4 +8Li+ +8e− →3Co+4Li2O (2) Co3V2O8 + xLi+ + xe− →3CoO+Li x V2O5 (3) CoO+2Li++ 2 e− ↔ Co+Li2O (4) Li x V2O5 + yLi+ + ye− ↔ Li x+y V2O5 Fig. 5 (a) showed the charge-discharge profiles of the Co3O4/ Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites at a current density of 100mA/g in a voltage window of 0.01–3V. The initial discharge curve had two significant potential plateaus at 0.89 and 0.45V, which shifted to the higher voltage in the subsequent cycles, in consistence with the above CV detection results. Moreover, the charge and discharge curves showed similar profiles from the 2nd to the 100th cycle, indicating highly stable lithiation/delithiation process. The initial discharge capacity was as high as 1664.2mAh/g, which was much higher than its theoretical capacity. The extra capacities could be attributed to the reversible formation of solid electrolyte interface (SEI) film resulting from the electrolyte degradation [7,39,43], which was common for metal-oxide based electrodes [22,26]. The discharge capacity of the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites mainly dropped at the subsequent cycles, maintaining of 1120.1mAh/g after 3 cycles. The irreversible capacity loss was mainly attributed to the formation of SEI film and irreversible formation of Li2O [44]. In contrast, Co3O4/Ni nanocomposites exhibited the lower initial discharge capacities of 1452 mAh/g than Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites, and retained at 968.7mAh/g after 3 cycles (Fig. 5(b)), indicating the distinct advantages of the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites. Fig. 5(c) showed the cyclability of the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni and Co3O4/Ni nanocomposites at a current density of 100mA/g. The discharge capacity of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites decreased in the initial 20 cycles, then maintained its capacity from the 20th to 40th cycle, but increased slowly after 40 cycles, and reached at a capacity of 1201.8mAh/g after 100 cycles. This phenomenon for the initial drop followed by gradual rise of the capacity was probably due to the reversible formation of a polymeric gel-like film derived from the decomposition of electrolyte [45], commonly occurring in various metal oxide anode materials [12,46]. Furthermore, the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites delivered Coulombic efficiency (CE) of 70.1% in the initial cycle, increased distinctly in the subsequent cycles and then gradually reached a stable level, delivering a mean value of 99.7% after 100 cycles, indicating the ascendant oxidation reduction conversion capability. For comparison, the discharge capacity of the Co3O4 /Ni nanocomposites rapidly dropped to 748.7mAh/g after 100 cycles, which was much lower than that of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites. The substantial enhancement of lithium ion storage capacity and stability of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites was attributed to their unique micro- structure and composition. On the one hand, the intercrossed and inlayed Co3O4/Co3V2O8 hybrid nanowires in the remaining free spaces between neighboring nanowires, maintained efficient electrolyte penetration and served as structure stabilizers, resulting in further substantial improvement of the battery capacity and stability [5,33]. On the other hand, both the Co3O4 and Co3V2O8 were active materials to reversibly undergo redox reactions with lithium ion, thus contributing to high lithium ion storage capacity. The capacity retention of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites was also higher than previously reported Co3O4-based, Co3V2O8-based and other anodes as summarized in Table S1 [19,27,32–34,38,39,47–53]. Apart from the high capacity and good cycling stability, the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites also exhibited significantly enhanced rate capabilities as shown in Fig. 5(d). After every ten cycles at a current rate, the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites showed excellent rate capability with discharge capacity of 1131.7, 1035.5, 954.3, 857.1 and 769.4mAh/g at the current densities of 0.1, 0.5, 1, 2 and 5A/g, respectively. Even when the current density was as high as 10A/g, the electrode could still deliver a capacity of 491.2mAh/g. This value of capacity was higher than the theoretical capacity of commercial graphite (372mAh/g). When the current density returned to 0.1 A/g, the specific capacity of 978mAh/g could be achieved. It was clearly seen that the electrochemical performance of the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni were superior to the Co3O4 /Ni. Such significantly enhanced rate performance of the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites in comparison with Co3O4/ Ni nanocomposites might be closely associated with their improved conductivity. To further understand the electrochemical performance, a long cycling performance of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites was conducted at a high current density of 1A/g. As shown in Fig. 5(e), the reversible capacity decreased slightly for the initial 200 cycles. However, the discharge capacity gradually increased in the following hundreds cycles, maintaining at 828.1mAh/g even after 600 cycles, The CE of the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites was almost close to 99.9% during the 600 cycles, indicating the highly reversible Li-storage process in cycling. For the investigation of possible reason for the excellent electrochemical performance of the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites, the structure and morphology variation of the as-prepared samples were studied after 100 cycles with charge state. As shown in Fig. 6 (a) and (b), the 3D network architecture disappeared and replaced by the compact and porous structure. Most of the Co3V2O8 and Co3O4 nanowires were pulverized into small particles and assembled to irregular shapes with the by-product adhering to their surface. The TEM result was consistent to those obtained from SEM as shown in Fig. 6(c). A HRTEM image of the cycled electrode (Fig. 6(d)) showed clear lattice fringes with interplanar spacing of 0.21nm, corresponding to the (111) planes of CoO. In addition, EDS elemental analysis (Fig. 6(e)–(h)) further displayed that Co, V and O were homogenously distributed in the porous structure, indicating that both the small sized Co3O4 and Co3V2O8 particles distributed uniformly throughout the porous structure in continuous direct contact with each other, rather than aggregating into large particles. The formation of this secondary porous structure upon cycling can be described as an electrochemical reconstruction [54,55], which accompanied by the initial size reduction of Co3V2O8 and Co3O4 nanowires to form nanoparticles and the assembly of these nanoparticles into secondary architecture. Furthermore, it can be seen that the nanowire morphology was partially preserved during the cycling process (Fig. 6(a)–(c), (e)–(h), indicating that 3D hybrid nanowires networks were beneficial to reduce the aggregation of 1D nanowires during the cycling process. The newly formed porous architecture facilitated enhance the reaction kinetics and the structure stability of the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni electrode, which could lead to the improved electrochemical performance. In contrast, the pure Co3O4 nanowires on Ni foam were seriously merged and aggregated to form a bulk shape with an increased diameter of around 500nm after the lithiation/delithiation cycles (Fig. S3). This might be responsible for the large difference in the rate and cycling performances of Co3O4 /Ni and Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni electrodes. To further study the origin of outstanding electrochemical performance of the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites, EIS spectra of the composites electrodes (0.01–100kHz, 5mV/s) were contrastively studied after different cycles as shown in Fig. 7 (a). The equivalent circuits were displayed in the inset of Fig. 7(a), where R s was the SEI film and/or contact resistance; R ct was the charge transfer resistance, and C dl was the capacitance related to the double layer, while Z w represented Warburg impedance associated with the Li-ion diffusion process within electrodes [56]. Table S3 listed the parameters of the equivalent circuit for the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites after fitting the diameter of the semicircular curve. Results showed that the R s of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites increased slightly upon cycling process, which might be relevant to the formation of SEI film in the initial discharge/charge process. The R ct of nanocomposites became smaller after 5 cycles than that of fresh electrode, which might be assigned to the electrochemical reconstruction in cycling that resulted in the formation of a secondary structure. The secondary structure of the nanocomposites facilitated the electric contact between Co3V2O8 and Co3O4, thus enhanced the charge transfer process of the integrated electrode, being in accordance with the SEM and TEM observation in Fig. 6. Moreover, the R ct after 5 cycles and 20 cycles displayed similar values, indicating highly stable charge transfer process of the electrode during the cycling process. Fig. 7(b) showed the EIS spectra of the fresh Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni and Co3O4/Ni nanocomposites. R s of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites was slightly smaller than that of Co3O4/Ni nanocomposites, indicating reduced ohmic resistance. This might be associated with the depressed formation of SEI film on the surface of the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites. Meanwhile, the R ct of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites was much smaller than that of Co3O4/Ni nanocomposites, showing enhanced electronic conductivity owing to the presence of the Co3V2O8 nanowires. As discussed above, the excellent electrochemical performance of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites was largely associated with the unique micro/nanostructures and component with several aspects: (1) The integrity of the synergetic/active Co3O4 and Co3V2O8 hybrid nanowires with 3D network can ensure a high electrical conductivity of the overall electrode due to the synergetic electron transportation system. The electrons could quickly flow into the Ni foam substrate through the different nanowires pathways [31,57]. (2) The intercrossed and inlayed Co3O4 and Co3V2O8 hybrid nanowires provided free spaces between neighboring nanowires, which facilitated the permeability of electrolyte and the diffusion of lithium ion between the nanowires. (3) The unique 3D network structure of the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites was beneficial to relieve the strain and reduce the aggregation of 1D nanowires induced by the volume variation during the long-term cycling process, thus improving cyclability. (4) Unique 3D structure of nanocomposites induced the formation of a secondary porous architecture during the cycling process. In this structure, small sized Co3O4 and Co3V2O8 particles distributed uniformly throughout the porous structure in continuous direct contact with each other, resulted in enhanced reaction kinetics and highly stable charge transfer process. (5) The porous and conductive Ni foam also played an important role in enhanced electrochemical performance, as it offered high porosity and a large surface area for efficient electrolyte diffusion throughout the electrode, and acted as a solid skeleton to ensure strong electrode integrity during the cycling process. 4 Conclusions In summary, the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites were successfully designed and fabricated by a stepwise hydrothermal method with a subsequent thermal treatment. They consisted of 1D Co3O4 nanowires on porous Ni foam and 1D Co3V2O8 nanowires that inlayed and adhered to parts of Co3O4 nanowires, forming a 3D hybrid nanowires network. When used as anode materials for LIBs, the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites exhibited high reversible Li-ion storage capacity of 1664.2mAh/g at 100mA/g, and remained 1201.8mAh/g after 100 cycles. The electrodes also showed excellent long-life cycle performance, which delivered no obvious capacity attenuation over 600 cycles at a specific current of 1A/g. Even when the current density was as high as 10A/g, The electrodes could still deliver a capacity of 491.2mAh/g. This confirmed that the Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites can greatly enhance the reversible capacity, cycling performance and rate capability. It was anticipated that the designed Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites in the present work could also be used in other fields. Furthermore, it was also expected that this strategy could be extended to construct other high-performance nanocomposites for the application of LIBs and other energy storage devices. coredata.dc:description: The Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites were rationally designed and prepared by a two-step hydrothermal synthesis and subsequent annealing treatment. The one-dimensional (1D) Co3O4 nanowire arrays directly grew on Ni foam, whereas the 1D Co3V2O8 nanowires adhered to parts of Co3O4 nanowires. Most of the hybrid nanowires were inlayed with each other, forming a 3D hybrid nanowires network. As a result, the discharge capacity of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites could reach 1201.8mAh/g after 100 cycles at 100mA/g. After 600 cycles at 1A/g, the discharge capacity was maintained at 828.1mAh/g. Moreover, even though the charge/discharge rates were increased to 10A/g, it rendered reversible capacity of 491.2mAh/g. The superior electrochemical properties of nanocomposites were probably ascribed to their unique 3D architecture and the synergistic effects of two active materials. Therefore, such Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites could potentially be used as anode materials for high-performance Li-ion batteries.
coredata.prism:publisher: Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by Elsevier B.V. and Science Press.
coredata.dc:title: The design and fabrication of Co3O4/Co3V2O8/Ni nanocomposites as high-performance anodes for Li-ion batteries
